Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project develops materials, training, and support structures for faculty to use in integrating game-themed content into their introductory computer programming courses with minimal impact on their existing curriculum. Through tutorials and workshops, faculty members are empowered to take advantage of game-themed Computer Science education to attract, engage, and retain students in introductory programming courses. A programming language-independent game-themed library is being defined based on previous platform-specific results. The library is then implemented based on Java and C#. A number of engaging demonstration examples, assignments, and tutorials are being designed and then implemented in Java and C#. Assessment of the effectiveness of using the new assignments and tutorials provides formative input in refining these materials. Each of the four teaching modules being developed abstracts and hides the details of computer graphics and games so that neither faculty nor students need any previous background in these areas. Additionally, the modules are self-contained and limited in scope so that faculty can pick and choose a subset to integrate into existing classes. The work is both student- and faculty-centric because it is designed to address the needs of both. Faculty at Cascadia Community College and North Seattle Community College, along with faculty at Willamette University, Evergreen State University, Johns Hopkins University, and the University of Washington Bothell are involved in testing the ease of use and efficacy of the materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is an integral part of the Game-Themed Research Group investigation at the University of Washington Bothell in exploring new, relevant, and engaging materials for delivering introductory programming concepts to empower educators in working with these materials. Our project is designed to support interested faculty members to selectively integrate casual game contents into their introductory programming courses with minimum impact on their existing curriculum and will thus be empowered to take advantage of the recent successes in game-themed CS education to further attract, engage, and retain students in introductory programming courses.

Intellectual Merit: We have designed a language independent casual game engine, implemented the game engine in two programming languages (C# and Java), engaged around 60 computer science and fine art students in building 5 causal games for teaching programming concepts, developed extensive teaching materials based on these games, recruited 8 professors in using the materials to teach their introductory programming classes (4 of the professors have no prior experience in computer graphics or videogames), studied and verified the effectiveness of the materials and our approach, refined the materials to facilitate more diverse approaches to teaching the related concepts, derived a process and are currently following and re-verifying the process for building casual games for teaching programming concepts with a team of undergraduate students in academic settings, demonstrated the potentials of using these materials as a recruit and outreach tool for engaging students from underserved backgrounds.

Broader Impacts: Our project addresses a significant and current problem—attracting more students to a STEM field—Computer Science. The results from our work are original, and creative: playing with fun and engaging casual games to study and analyze structured problem solving followed by hands-on experience with programming language constructs to build simpler versions of the same games. The initial deployment phase demonstrated success in reaching students while maintaining the desired learning outcomes. Faculty members with no relevant background in computer graphics and games were able to integrate the materials in their existing curricula. All developed materials are freely available online (https://depts.washington.edu/cmmr/GTCS/).

Because of the originality of our investigation, there are three categories of additional impacts. (1) Videogame design. Our casual games for teaching CS1 concepts pose unique requirements: in additional to being fun and engaging, our games must allow accessible and re-programmable game logic and controls. Our approach to addressing this challenge has been focusing on and designing engaging challenges based on well-understood evergreen mechanics. This unique approach to videogame design has resulted in a to be released commercial videogame with one other being developed for release in Fall 2016. (2) Casual game building approach. We have published two books, one on building game engines for developing casual games, and the second on approaches to building casual games, based on designing and building the five casual games for this project. (3) Effective outreach tool. Our preliminary results demonstrated that, with proper refinements, our materials can be used effectively as recruitment or outreach tools for engaging students from diverse backgrounds.
